_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Yabucoa Wastewater Treatment Plant is located at the State Road PR-901 Int. PR-3 Km 0.1 Bo. Juan Martin, Yabucoa Puerto Rico, 00767.  This water treatment plant (1.5 MGD) is owned by Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) which is a Government Agency.  PRASA has developed the RMP following the Program #3 for the Management and Prevention of Risks associated with the storage and handling of the toxic substance used as for water disinfection: Chlorine.  The RMP was prepared in compliance with EPA 40 CFR Part 68.  The Prevention Program was prepared in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, as established in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.

Accidental Release:
It is PRASA policy to comply with EPA and OSHA Federal and State applicable requirements. Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by EPA, for that reason Yabucoa Wastewater Treatment Plant is observing the appropriated engineering controls.  Changes have been put in place to improve safety and as a part of the Prevention Plan implanted to protect the wellness of workers, employees, contractors, visitors and immediately surrounding areas and inhabitants.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance handled.
Yabucoa Wastewater Treatment Plant is located close to the Ca?o Santiago where the plant discharges the treated water.  The chlorine is used as a disinfectant to destroy the microorganism that could cause illness in humans and contamination of the Ca?o Santiago.
The chlorine is delivered from the PRASA Chlorine Warehouse and Distribution Center at Puerto Nuevo to the plant in one (1) ton containers.  Yabucoa Wastewater Treatment Plant could have a  maximum storage capacity of 10,000 pounds distributed in ten (10) containers.  Two containers are connected to chlorinators only one container is used ata time. The chlorine flows to the vacuum chlorinator and from it the chlorine is sent to the contact chamber, through a underground pipeline, where it is combined with the used water at th

e end of plant?s process at a rate of 30 to 40 pounds per day. 

Worst Case Scenario:
The Worst Case Scenario was determined as indicated in the EPA Wastewater Treatment Plant, as per Appendix F Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.  This guidance considers the release of the Chlorine Gas of the entire container (2,000 pounds) during 10 minutes and other specifications related to the weather conditions and a radio of 3.0 miles on rural areas, for a chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene Association exposure limit above which it is determined human health will be affected.  Using the Landview 6 Simulator and the US Census 2000, it was identified that 24,263 public receptors are inside the 3.0 miles radio.  No known environmental receptors (state parks, or official designated wildlife preserves) are located within this radio area.  The ALOHA Modeling Dispersion Program was used to simulate the gas dispersion.

Alternative Case Scenario:
The more realistic scenario was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plants parameters, as a release of the total content of a 2,000 pounds container, but throughout a 3/8 inch pipe leak.  In such case the end point distance is calculated as 0.2 miles on rural areas and 149 public receptors were identified over the most recent map.  No known environmental receptors are located within the radio area.

General Accident Release Prevention Program 
PRASA is actually in a very aggressive operation to implement a Prevention Plan to ensure the maintenance and mechanical integrity of the facility which will improve significantly the safety scope of the current prevention plans.  Standard Operational Procedures (SOP?s) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties aware of the hazardous and risk related to the chlorine.  List of all SOP?s are indicated in the PSM report and are locat

ed in the plant.

Emergency Response Program:
PRASA has various SOP?s to manage emergency programs associated to a release of the chemical and also related to the emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics events.

Five years Accident History:
No mayor release of chlorine in excess of ten (10) pounds has been reported during the last five years. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
PRASA has implemented in Yabucoa Wastewater Treatment Plant, a vacuum operated system to improve the control of the process and the safety of the chlorine handling and storage.  It is still needed to reinforced administrative activities related to containers handling and transportation,  preventive maintenance and audits. Recommendations were given on that regard on last PHA dated February 27, 2009.
